sn22.78:1.2.pli: “Sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā sāyanhasamayaṃ āsayā nikkhamati; āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhati; vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuviloketi; samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati; tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkamati.
sn22.78:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den, yawns, surveys the four quarters, and roars his lion’s roar three times. Then he sets out on the hunt.

sn22.78:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, tiracchānagatā pāṇā sīhassa migarañño nadato saddaṃ suṇanti; yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti; bilaṃ bilāsayā pavisanti; dakaṃ dakāsayā pavisanti; vanaṃ vanāsayā pavisanti; ākāsaṃ pakkhino bhajanti.
sn22.78:1.3.eng: And whatever animals hear the roar of the lion, king of beasts, are typically filled with fear, awe, and terror. They return to their lairs, be they in a hole, the water, or a wood; and the birds take to the air.

sn22.78:1.4.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, rañño nāgā gāmanigamarājadhānīsu, daḷhehi varattehi baddhā, tepi tāni bandhanāni sañchinditvā sampadāletvā bhītā muttakarīsaṃ cajamānā, yena vā tena vā palāyanti.
sn22.78:1.4.eng: Even the royal elephants, bound with strong harness in the villages, towns, and capital cities, break apart their bonds, and urinate and defecate in terror as they flee here and there.

sn22.78:1.5.pli: Evaṃ mahiddhiko kho, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā tiracchānagatānaṃ pāṇānaṃ, evaṃ mahesakkho, evaṃ mahānubhāvo.
sn22.78:1.5.eng: That’s how powerful is the lion, king of beasts, over animals, how illustrious and mighty.

sn22.78:2.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yadā tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā. So dhammaṃ deseti:
sn22.78:2.1.eng: In the same way, when a Realized One arises in the world—perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed—he teaches the Dhamma:

sn22.78:2.2.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
sn22.78:2.2.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the disappearance of form.

sn22.78:2.6.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
sn22.78:2.6.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.’

sn22.78:2.7.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, devā dīghāyukā vaṇṇavanto sukhabahulā uccesu vimānesu ciraṭṭhitikā tepi tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti:
sn22.78:2.7.eng: Now, there are gods who are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy, living for ages in their divine palaces. When they hear this teaching by the Realized One, they’re typically filled with fear, awe, and terror.

sn22.78:2.8.pli: ‘aniccāva kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā niccamhāti amaññimha.
sn22.78:2.8.eng: ‘Oh no! It turns out we’re impermanent, though we thought we were permanent!

sn22.78:2.9.pli: Addhuvāva kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā dhuvamhāti amaññimha.
sn22.78:2.9.eng: It turns out we don’t last, though we thought we were everlasting!

sn22.78:2.10.pli: Asassatāva kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā sassatamhāti amaññimha.
sn22.78:2.10.eng: It turns out we’re short-lived, though we thought we were eternal!

sn22.78:2.11.pli: Mayampi kira, bho, aniccā addhuvā asassatā sakkāyapariyāpannā’ti.
sn22.78:2.11.eng: It turns out that we’re impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, and included within substantial reality.’
sn22.78:2.11.comm: When the same parable is told at AN 4.33, it is in response to the Buddha’s teaching on “substantial reality”, lending the discourse greater coherence. Since the aggregates are elsewhere said to be “substantial reality”, perhaps the parable was adapted in this form.

sn22.78:2.12.pli: Evaṃ mahiddhiko kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato sadevakassa lokassa, evaṃ mahesakkho, evaṃ mahānubhāvo”ti.
sn22.78:2.12.eng: That’s how powerful is the Realized One in the world with its gods, how illustrious and mighty.”

sn22.78:2.13.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn22.78:2.14.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn22.78:3.2.eng: in all the world with its gods,

sn22.78:3.3.eng: rolls forth the Wheel of Dhamma

sn22.78:4.4.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

sn22.78:5.3.eng: are afraid and full of terror,

sn22.78:5.4.eng: like the other beasts when they hear a lion.

sn22.78:6.3.eng: So they say when they hear the word

sn22.78:6.4.eng: of the perfected one, free and unaffected.”

sn22.79:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussaramānā anussaranti sabbete pañcupādānakkhandhe anussaranti etesaṃ vā aññataraṃ.
sn22.79:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins recollect many kinds of past lives, all recollect the five grasping aggregates, or one of them.
sn22.79:1.2.comm: Compare the stock description of such recollection: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended” (eg. SN 16.9:13.1). Also see the different ways the self is conceived as being reborn in states described as “percipient”, “formed”, and so on in DN 1.

sn22.79:1.4.eng: ‘I had such form in the past.’

sn22.79:1.5.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, anussaramāno rūpaṃyeva anussarati.
sn22.79:1.5.eng: Recollecting thus, it’s only form that they recollect.

sn22.79:1.7.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, anussaramāno vedanaṃyeva anussarati.

sn22.79:1.11.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, anussaramāno viññāṇameva anussarati.
sn22.79:1.11.eng: Recollecting thus, it’s only consciousness that they recollect.

sn22.79:2.1.eng: And why do you call it form?

sn22.79:2.2.eng: It’s deformed; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.

sn22.79:2.4.pli: Sītenapi ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppati, jighacchāyapi ruppati, pipāsāyapi ruppati, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassenapi ruppati.
sn22.79:2.4.eng: Deformed by cold, heat, hunger, and thirst, and deformed by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles.

sn22.79:2.5.eng: It’s deformed; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.
sn22.79:2.5.comm: For the other aggregates, the noun is illustrated with the verb, but rūpa has no verbal form. Instead, the text puns with the unrelated verb ruppati. Ruppati would be better translated as “inflict”, but I use “deform” to maintain the play on words. The actual etymology of rūpa is unclear (see note on SN 12.2:11.5).

sn22.79:3.1.eng: And why do you call it feeling?

sn22.79:3.2.eng: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.

sn22.79:3.4.pli: Sukhampi vedayati, dukkhampi vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedayati.
sn22.79:3.4.eng: It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral.

sn22.79:3.5.eng: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.

sn22.79:4.1.eng: And why do you call it perception?

sn22.79:4.2.eng: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.

sn22.79:4.4.pli: Nīlampi sañjānāti, pītakampi sañjānāti, lohitakampi sañjānāti, odātampi sañjānāti.
sn22.79:4.4.eng: It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white.
sn22.79:4.4.comm: “Color” is a more sophisticated and less universal aspect of awareness than “feeling”, reflecting the fact that “perception” relates to higher-order functions like recognition and interpretation, which are involved in concept formation.

sn22.79:4.5.eng: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.

sn22.79:5.1.eng: And why do you call them choices?

sn22.79:5.2.eng: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:5.2.comm: The text uses three forms of the same word. A literal rendering might be: “They activate the activated; that’s why they’re called activators.”

sn22.79:5.3.eng: And what are the conditioned phenomena that they produce?

sn22.79:5.4.pli: Rūpaṃ rūpattāya saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharonti, vedanaṃ vedanattāya saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharonti, saññaṃ saññattāya saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharonti, saṅkhāre saṅkhārattāya saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharonti, viññāṇaṃ viññāṇattāya saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharonti.
sn22.79:5.4.eng: Form is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into form. Feeling is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into feeling. Perception is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into perception. Choices are conditioned phenomena; choices are what make them into choices. Consciousness is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into consciousness.
sn22.79:5.4.comm: Literally, “they make conditioned form into the state of being form”.

sn22.79:5.5.eng: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:5.5.comm: The aggregates in this life were generated by the kammic choices in past lives, and continue to be shaped by choices in this life. Unless kammically potent choices are relinquished, they will go on to generate future lives as well.

sn22.79:6.1.eng: And why do you call it consciousness?

sn22.79:6.2.eng: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.

sn22.79:6.4.pli: Ambilampi vijānāti, tittakampi vijānāti, kaṭukampi vijānāti, madhurampi vijānāti, khārikampi vijānāti, akhārikampi vijānāti, loṇikampi vijānāti, aloṇikampi vijānāti.
sn22.79:6.4.eng: It cognizes sour, bitter, pungent, sweet, hot, mild, salty, and bland.
sn22.79:6.4.comm: It seems that taste was a common way of illustrating consciousness. Aitareya Upaniṣad 3.1 describes the Self as that by which one sees, hears, smells, tastes, speaks, and “cognizes sweet and sour” (svādu cāsvādu ca vijānāti). Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.2.4 says “one cognizes tastes with the tongue”. The explanation at MN 43:4.5 differs, as there it is talking about meditation, not rebirth.

sn22.79:6.5.eng: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.

sn22.79:7.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
sn22.79:7.1.eng: A learned noble disciple reflects on this:

sn22.79:7.2.comm: The verb “bite” is used as a vivid image for the way the aggregates constantly afflict or “itch”. Compare the Vedic image of Indra as the “dragon-biter” (Rig Veda 3.45.2). Here it can also be seen as continuing the idea of consciousness as the taster.

sn22.79:7.3.pli: Atītampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva rūpena khajjiṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannena rūpena khajjāmi.
sn22.79:7.3.eng: In the past I was also bitten by form just like now.

sn22.79:7.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana anāgataṃ rūpaṃ abhinandeyyaṃ, anāgatampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva rūpena khajjeyyaṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannena rūpena khajjāmī’ti.
sn22.79:7.4.eng: If I were to look forward to enjoying form in the future, I’d be bitten by form in the future just as I am today.’

sn22.79:7.5.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya atītasmiṃ rūpasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.79:7.5.eng: Reflecting like this they are not concerned with past form,

sn22.79:7.6.eng: they don’t look forward to enjoying future form,

sn22.79:7.7.pli: paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn22.79:7.7.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present form.

sn22.79:8.2.pli: Atītampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva vedanāya khajjiṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannāya vedanāya khajjāmi.

sn22.79:8.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana anāgataṃ vedanaṃ abhinandeyyaṃ;

sn22.79:8.4.pli: anāgatampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva vedanāya khajjeyyaṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannāya vedanāya khajjāmī’ti.

sn22.79:8.5.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya atītāya vedanāya anapekkho hoti;

sn22.79:8.7.pli: paccuppannāya vedanāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn22.79:9.3.pli: Atītampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva saṅkhārehi khajjiṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannehi saṅkhārehi khajjāmīti.

sn22.79:9.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana anāgate saṅkhāre abhinandeyyaṃ;

sn22.79:9.5.pli: anāgatampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva saṅkhārehi khajjeyyaṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannehi saṅkhārehi khajjāmī’ti.

sn22.79:9.6.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya atītesu saṅkhāresu anapekkho hoti;

sn22.79:9.8.pli: paccuppannānaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn22.79:10.2.pli: Atītampi addhānaṃ evameva viññāṇena khajjiṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannena viññāṇena khajjāmi.
sn22.79:10.2.eng: In the past I was also bitten by consciousness just like now.

sn22.79:10.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana anāgataṃ viññāṇaṃ abhinandeyyaṃ;
sn22.79:10.3.eng: If I were to look forward to enjoying consciousness in the future, I’d be bitten by consciousness in the future just as I am today.’

sn22.79:10.4.pli: anāgatampāhaṃ addhānaṃ evameva viññāṇena khajjeyyaṃ, seyyathāpi etarahi paccuppannena viññāṇena khajjāmī’ti.

sn22.79:10.5.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya atītasmiṃ viññāṇasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.79:10.5.eng: Reflecting like this they are not concerned with past consciousness,

sn22.79:10.6.eng: they don’t look forward to enjoying future consciousness,

sn22.79:10.7.pli: paccuppannassa viññāṇassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn22.79:10.7.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present consciousness.

sn22.79:11.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.79:11.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.79:11.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.79:11.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.79:11.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.79:11.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.79:11.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.79:11.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.79:11.16.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.79:11.17.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.79:11.19.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.79:11.19.eng: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.79:11.20.eng: You should truly see any kind of feeling …

sn22.79:11.23.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.79:11.23.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.79:12.1.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako apacināti, no ācināti;
sn22.79:12.1.eng: This is called a noble disciple who gets rid of and doesn’t accumulate;

sn22.79:12.2.eng: who gives up and doesn’t grasp;

sn22.79:12.3.comm: The verbs visineti and ussineti, unique to this passage, are from the root si, “bind”.

sn22.79:12.4.eng: who dissipates and doesn’t get clouded.

sn22.79:12.5.eng: And what things do they get rid of and not accumulate?

sn22.79:12.6.eng: They get rid of form and don’t accumulate it.

sn22.79:12.11.eng: And what things do they give up and not grasp?

sn22.79:12.12.eng: They give up form and don’t grasp it.

sn22.79:12.17.eng: And what things do they unmesh and not enmesh?

sn22.79:12.18.eng: They unmesh form and don’t enmesh it.

sn22.79:12.23.eng: And what things do they dissipate and not get clouded by?

sn22.79:12.24.eng: They dissipate form and don’t get clouded by it.

sn22.79:12.28.eng: consciousness and don’t get clouded by it.

sn22.79:13.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi … saññāyapi … saṅkhāresupi … viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.79:13.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.79:13.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.79:13.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.79:13.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn22.79:13.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.79:14.1.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nevācināti na apacināti, apacinitvā ṭhito; neva pajahati na upādiyati, pajahitvā ṭhito; neva visineti na ussineti, visinetvā ṭhito; neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhito
sn22.79:14.1.eng: This is called a mendicant who neither gets rid of nor accumulates, but remains after getting rid. They neither give up nor grasp, but remain after giving up. They neither unmesh nor enmesh, but remain after unmeshing. They neither dissipate nor get clouded, but remain after dissipating.
sn22.79:14.1.comm: “Remain” (ṭhita) means “live on”. This passage concerns the arahant before his final passing. This passage recalls the one who “neither picks up nor puts down” in the Aṭṭhakavagga (eg. Snp 4.3:8.3).

sn22.79:14.2.pli: Kiñca nevācināti na apacināti, apacinitvā ṭhito?
sn22.79:14.2.eng: And what things do they neither get rid of nor accumulate, but remain after getting rid of them?

sn22.79:14.3.pli: Rūpaṃ nevācināti na apacināti, apacinitvā ṭhito;
sn22.79:14.3.eng: They neither get rid of nor accumulate form, but remain after getting rid of it.

sn22.79:14.4.eng: They neither get rid of nor accumulate feeling …

sn22.79:14.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ nevācināti na apacināti, apacinitvā ṭhito.
sn22.79:14.7.eng: consciousness, but remain after getting rid of it.

sn22.79:14.8.pli: Kiñca neva pajahati na upādiyati, pajahitvā ṭhito?
sn22.79:14.8.eng: And what things do they neither give up nor grasp, but remain after giving them up?

sn22.79:14.9.pli: Rūpaṃ neva pajahati na upādiyati, pajahitvā ṭhito;
sn22.79:14.9.eng: They neither give up nor grasp form, but remain after giving it up.

sn22.79:14.10.eng: They neither give up nor grasp feeling …

sn22.79:14.13.pli: viññāṇaṃ neva pajahati na upādiyati, pajahitvā ṭhito.
sn22.79:14.13.eng: consciousness, but remain after giving it up.

sn22.79:14.14.pli: Kiñca neva visineti na ussineti, visinetvā ṭhito?
sn22.79:14.14.eng: And what things do they neither discard nor amass, but remain after discarding them?

sn22.79:14.15.pli: Rūpaṃ neva visineti na ussineti, visinetvā ṭhito;
sn22.79:14.15.eng: They neither unmesh nor enmesh form, but remain after unmeshing it.

sn22.79:14.16.eng: They neither unmesh nor enmesh feeling …

sn22.79:14.19.pli: viññāṇaṃ neva visineti na ussineti, visinetvā ṭhito.
sn22.79:14.19.eng: consciousness, but remain after unmeshing it.

sn22.79:14.20.pli: Kiñca neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti, vidhūpetvā ṭhito?
sn22.79:14.20.eng: And what things do they neither dissipate nor get clouded by, but remain after dissipating them?

sn22.79:14.21.pli: Rūpaṃ neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti, vidhūpetvā ṭhito;
sn22.79:14.21.eng: They neither dissipate nor get clouded by form, but remain after dissipating it.

sn22.79:14.22.eng: They neither dissipate nor get clouded by feeling …

sn22.79:14.25.pli: viññāṇaṃ neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti, vidhūpetvā ṭhito.
sn22.79:14.25.eng: consciousness, but remain after dissipating it.

sn22.79:14.26.pli: Evaṃvimuttacittaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ saindā devā sabrahmakā sapajāpatikā ārakāva namassanti:
sn22.79:14.26.eng: When a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, the gods together with Indra, the Divinity, and the Progenitor worship them from afar:

sn22.79:15.2.eng: Homage to you, supreme among men!

sn22.79:15.4.comm: Elsewhere, this verse expresses the mystic wonder of these deities at the depth of an arahant’s meditation and that upon which it is based (AN 11.9, Thag 18.1:34.4). Here it seems less pertinent, as there has been no mention of meditation and its basis.

sn22.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you how grasping leads to anxiety, and how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.

sn22.8:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.

sn22.8:1.4.eng: And how does grasping lead to anxiety?

sn22.8:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano rūpaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati.
sn22.8:1.5.eng: It’s when an unlearned ordinary person regards form like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.8:1.5.comm: This directly rejects all forms of self, especially the conceptions of self as expressed in the Upaniṣads. | Etaṁ mama occurs as mamedaṁ (“this is mine”, Maitrī Upaniṣad 3.2), which in context is a limited view of self. An illegitimate king betrays his country with the thought, “It is not mine” (na etan mama, Arthaśāstra 8.2.08). | Eso’hamasmi is Yājñavalkya’s so’hamasmi (“I am that”, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.1; BU 5.15.1 = Īśā Upaniṣad 16; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.11.1, 4.12.1, 4.13.1; Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 3.6), which Uddālaka’s tattvamasi puts in second person (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.8.7). | The same passage also parallels eso me attā with sa ātmā (“that is the self”), for which we also find eṣa ma ātmā (CU 3.14.3), and in the optative mood, ma idaṁ syād ātman (BU 1.2.7).

sn22.8:1.6.pli: Tassa taṃ rūpaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.8:1.6.eng: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.8:1.7.eng: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.8:1.11.pli: viññāṇaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati.
sn22.8:1.11.eng: consciousness like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

sn22.8:1.12.pli: Tassa taṃ viññāṇaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.8:1.12.eng: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.8:1.13.eng: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.8:1.14.eng: That’s how grasping leads to anxiety.

sn22.8:2.1.eng: And how does not grasping lead to freedom from anxiety?

sn22.8:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
sn22.8:2.2.eng: It’s when a learned noble disciple regards form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.8:2.3.pli: Tassa taṃ rūpaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.8:2.3.eng: When that form of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.8:2.4.eng: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.8:2.8.pli: viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
sn22.8:2.8.eng: consciousness like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.8:2.9.pli: Tassa taṃ viññāṇaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.8:2.9.eng: When that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.8:2.10.eng: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.8:2.11.eng: That’s how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.”
